title: How do neutron stars turn into black holes? - Quora

response.answer_text: Extremely rarely. Almost all neutron stars that have ever formed are still here. Most neutron stars have lasted for billions of years. The exceptions are those younger than that. Nearly all black holes result from core collapse in stars too big to form neutron stars. They are often called failed supernovas, because the core bounce fails to produce an explosion. The outgoing shock stalls and then reverses, so that nearly all of the star falls into the newly formed black hole. Larger black holes form from mergers of smaller ones, as LIGO and other gravitational wave observatories have seen. It is possible for a neutron star in a binary system with a supergiant companion to accrete matter from the other star, and go over the Tolman-Oppenheimer-Volkhov limit, at which point it will collapse into a black hole.It is possible for two neutron stars in a binary system to merge and form a black hole. LIGO and VIRGO have observed such an event in gravitational waves. It is not certain whether the result was a very large neutron star or a very small black hole, but we expect to find others with clearer results.It is possible for a neutron star to fall into a supergiant star, and migrate to its center, forming a Thorne-Zhitkov object. There is then a very thin layer in which matter fuses, turns to neutrons, and accretes to the body of the neutron star over millions of years. The accreting matter releases enough energy to hold up the rest of the star during that time. At some point, the neutron star can collapse to a black hole, and the remainder of the star surrounding it will form a very large accretion disk before most of it gradually falls in and some is thrown out in polar jets.It is possible for some other object such as a white dwarf to run into a neutron star, and provide enough matter to push it over the limit. Or maybe not. Maybe the white dwarf would go supernova at that point.

A supernova results in either a neutron star (between 1.4 and 3 solar masses), a quark star(about 3 solar masses), or a black hole(greater than 3 solar masses), which is the remaining collapsed core of the star. During a supernova, most of the stellar mass is blown off into space, forming elements heavier than iron which cannot be generated through stellar nucleosynthesis, because beyond iron, the star requires more energy to fuse the atoms than it gets back. During the supernova collapse, the atoms in the core break up into electrons, protons and neutrons. In the case that the supernova results in a neutron star core, the electrons and protons in the core are merged to become neutrons, so the newly born 20-km-diameter neutron star containing between 1.4 and 3 solar masses is like a giant atomic nucleus containing only neutrons.If the neutron star's mass is then increased, neutrons become degenerate, breaking up into their constituent quarks, thus the star becomes a quark star; a further increase in mass results in a black hole. When you talk about a black hole with a stable mass (at least 3 solar masses), it is good to consider that they come in 4 flavors: rotating-charged, rotating-uncharged, non-rotating-charged, non-rotating-uncharged. What we would see visually during the transformation would be a hard radiation flash. This is because during the collapse, the particles on/near the surface have time to emit hard radiation as they break up before going into the event horizon; so this could be one of the causes of gamma ray bursts (GRBs).We know that atoms break up into protons, neutrons, electrons under pressure. Under more pressure, protons and electrons combine into neutrons. Under even more pressure, neutrons break down into quarks. Under still more pressure, perhaps quarks break down into still smaller particles. (Not really proved, but theories suggest they break down into smaller articles) Ultimately the smallest particle is a string: open or closed loop, and has a Planck length, which is many orders of magnitude smaller than a quark. if a string is magnified so it is 1 millimeter in length, then a proton would have a diameter that would fit snugly between the Sun and Epsilon Eridani, 10.5 light years away; that's how big a proton is compared to a string, so you can imagine there are perhaps quite a few intermediate things between quarks and strings. A string is pure energy and Einstein said mass is just a form of energy, so the collapse into a black hole really breaks down the structure of energy that gives the appearance of mass/matter/baryonic particles, and leaves the mass in its most simple form, open or closed strings, that is, pure energy bound by gravity. We know that black holes (which are not really holes or singularities, as they do have mass, radius, rotation, charge and hence density, which varies with radius) can evaporate, giving up their entire mass in the form of radiation, thus proving they are actually energy. Evaporation of a black hole occurs if its mass is below the minimum mass of a stable black hole, which is 3 solar masses; the Schwarzschild radius equation even tells you what the radius of a black hole is given its mass, and vice versa. Coming back to the question , a simple way for a neutron star to become more massive in order to be able to turn into a black hole is to be part of a binary system, where it is close enough to another star that the neutron star and its binary pair orbit each other, and the neutron star siphons off gas from the other star, thus gaining mass. Neutron stars can be thought of as a collection of giant synchrotrons: circular particle accelerators which radiate light. In the case of a type of neutron star called a pulsar, the electrons and protons within the star circulate asymmetrically and send out pulses of light out into space. At least, this is the story that we tell ourselves about the pulsed light which Jocelyn Bell discovered emerging from outer space. The process of a neutron star turning into a black hole would involve the speed with which the charged particles circulate around the star increasing until the particles are moving at the speed of light. For this to happen, the size of the star has to shrink without energy loss or you have to add mass to the star. But how does this picture mesh with descriptions of gravity and inertia as the result of a collective, coherent oscillation or (equivalently) an accelerating expansion of space? If the protons and electrons are all moving radially in and out in a breathing motion, radiating light waves which add up to create the gravitational field around the star, then an increase in gravitational field would correspond to a faster radial oscillation. Stronger gravity would also cause faster rotation and a smaller radius. A movement towards a smaller radius gives an inward kick to the radial oscillation which would increase the energy of the oscillation and thereby increase the strength of the gravitational field, and so on until the whole thing collapses in on itself. I didn’t mention synchroton radiation tangential to the circulating motion. That would be an important mechanism for removing energy from the system and the degree to which this happens seems to be open to debate. It is a nice story and one can also tell it in terms of electron degeneracy pressure and Ehrenfest’s paradox. After writing this description, I wonder if it is not a plain-language echo of the idea that Hawking radiation has a backreaction effect which increases the energy density at the event horizon and causes black holes to evaporate before they have a chance to form. https://arxiv.org/pdf/1406.1525v1.pdf With this perspective, when a red giant bubble pops you either end up with a droplet of jiggling liquid (a neutron star or white dwarf) or nothing. You don’t end up with a singularity which persists for an eternity. Just food for thought.  National Schools' Observatory

Stars are held up - and are stable due to the balance between gravity and internal pressures generated due to the fusion reaction. Towards the end of their life, smaller stars collapse into white dwarf stars, where they are held up by the electron degeneracy pressure. According to the Pauli exclusion principle, no two electrons with the same spin can occupy the same energy state in the same volume. After the lowest energy level is filled, the other electrons are forced into higher and higher energy states with the result, they travel at progressively higher speeds. These high speed electrons create a pressure known as 'degenerate electron pressure' which is capable of supporting a star! Spin and the Pauli Exclusion Principle While white dwarfs are supported against gravitational collapse, there is an upper limit to the mass of a white dwarf at 1.40 solar masses, known as the Chandrasekhar Limit named after Subramaniam Chandrasekhar (1910-1995) the famous Indian born American astrophysicist who derived it. The limit arises due to the physics of electron degeneracy. As the mass of a white dwarf approaches the Chandrasekhar limit, gravity attempts to squeeze the star into a smaller volume, forcing electrons to occupy higher energy states and attain faster velocities. At this limit, the pressure exerted by the electrons travelling at close to the speed of light is not sufficient to support the star, and so the white dwarf collapses into a much denser state - a neutron star. Neutron stars are very small - typically with a radius of only about 10 kilometres, but super dense – they produce gravitational fields comparable to that of black holes. Neutron Stars: Definition & Facts According to latest research, neutron stars have an upper limit to their mass, at 2.16 solar masses beyond which they too collapse to become quark stars . According to theory, when a neutron star is put under sufficient pressure either from its own gravity or the initial pressure that created it, the neutrons break down into quarks - forming what is known as quark matter. However, this is only a hypothesis. Afterall, neutrons are made of quarks, therefore it is theorized that the degeneracy pressure keeping the quarks apart within the neutrons might break down in much the same way, creating an ultra-dense phase of degenerate matter based on densely packed quarks. However, scientists are not yet certain whether or not it actually happens in reality. Finally, if the mass exceeds 2.16 solar masses, the star literally disappears - becoming a singularity. In other words, a black hole. Neutron star upper limit found

There are two ways that a neutron star can turn into a black hole, but in both cases the mass of the neutron star must be very close to what is needed to become a black hole. The first way is for the neutron star to accrete more matter.  This could come from another star in a close orbit or from random bits of matter that it runs into over a long period of time. The second way works for a neutron star that already has enough mass to form a black hole but doesn't due to a very rapid rotation.  The rapid rotation reduces the effects of the gravitational field that would otherwise cause an unstoppable implosion.  However, neutron stars lose rotational energy over time, and as the rate of rotation decreases, the chance of forming a black hole increases.

Normally not. A neutron star is by definition not heavy enough to collapse into a black hole. The only way it can later become heavy enough, is something else adding (usually a lot of) mass to it. This does happen. A recent LIGO observation was the final stage of two neutron stars orbiting each other. For billions of years they’d been shedding energy by gravitational radiation, and getting closer and closer . Eventually they merged, and the combined mass almost immediately collapsed. More commonly a neutron star may be orbiting close to an ordinary star. As that star ages it will get larger, and the neutron star will accumulate mass from the other star’s atmosphere. Again, this may add enough mass to result in a collapse. Presumably there exist isolated neutron stars only ever so slightly below the mass threshold for collapsing, which might be pushed over the edge by billions of years of accumulation of interstellar gas and dust.
